Slower web development

February 26, 2019

Lately, I have read stuff that have made web development a lot more of a nuanced craft for me. It mostly concerns ethics, sustainability, web standards, and the open web platform itself.

From surveillance capitalism to impending global climate collapse, questions of ethics and sustainability have become more prominent in public consciousness lately. Increasingly, they need to be taken into account in our decision-making process. And that includes web development!

Caring about web performances, bundle sizes, semantic, accessibility to people with different genetic makeup and circumstances ‚Äî these things affect lives and environment. Admittedly, they are not easy ‚Äî or even realistic given the current pervasive break-neck culture ‚Äî to carry out, but learning, advocating and doing them in the daily live as a developer would be, in my opinion, a good practice to build the character, attitude and sensibility that would prove to be useful when we impact the world outside of our job.

The following sections are the few areas in front-end development that I think currently violate ethics and sustainability, and how they were due to eschewing the web standards and platform itself, largely in favor of developer‚Äôs experience(DX) rather than user‚Äôs experience(UX). I should also add that much of this was written from the perspective of a ‚Äòindie hacker‚Äô/designer; I'm most likely missing something and you might disagree with the technicalities, but please try to consider their implications in terms of ethics and sustainability in a broader context.

CSS

The first big one that I don‚Äôt see more people talking about is the ubiquitous usage and butchering of CSS classes. Do you know that classes were never really meant for styling in the markup level? Classes should be used mainly for grouping elements, doing layout, and the occasional styling of element‚Äôs states ‚Äî if you must ‚Äî for example giving a button red background color.

Here is what the web standard body W3C have to say in that regard:

CSS gives so much power to the ‚Äúclass‚Äù attribute, that in many cases it doesn‚Äôt matter what HTML element the class is set on ‚Äî you can make any element emulate almost any other. Relying on this power is not recommended, since it removes the level of structure that has a universal meaning (HTML elements). A structure based on ‚Äúclass‚Äù is only useful within a restricted domain, where the meaning of a class has been mutually agreed upon.

Here are two instrumental articles that upended my worldview on front-end development:

  • Meaningful CSS: Style Like You Mean It
  • CSS Inheritance, The Cascade And Global Scope: Your New Old Worst Best Friends

My takeaway from those two articles was: you know those cutting edge CSS practices and tools like the BEM, OOCSS, Tailwind CSS, and CSS-in-JS libraries? Well, you don‚Äôt need them! Here are the reasons: they bloat web pages, make pages less semantic, make front-end development less accessible to HTML/CSS trained designer/developer folks, and dramatically increase the learning curve and barrier of entry for new people. Always try to leverage CSS‚Äôs built-in mechanism! Read the articles!

We don‚Äôt need more CSS frameworks too. They bloat. Think twice before throwing in Bootstrap‚Äôs massive load of classes. If you have read the two articles shared above, you would have an idea styling your UI components. You don‚Äôt have to do it all in one huge index.css file either; you can break it up into individual[component_name].css files, then put them together with webpack.

Also avoid any frameworks for CSS Flexbox and CSS grid because themselves are the framework already! And to complete this crusade, hell, avoid SCSS too! Instead, opt for calc and custom variables. Lots of people fancy the nesting capability in SCSS. I get it, I loved it too ‚Äî it‚Äôs convenient and it just seemed so‚Ä¶logical. But if you nest according to the markup, it quickly gets out of hand, producing long chained selectors, bloating CSS files and reduces CSS parsing performance in the browser.

However, I do realize that SCSS would help maintainability in some use cases, such as building a fluid typography system. And if I do use it, I would remind myself not to add too many abstractions(that reminds me of the AHA programming principle); keep it readable for entry-level programmers. üíå

Javascript

I have also started weighing rigorously the merits of front-end frameworks, specifically React, before using one in my projects.

Until recently, I had always been a big believer in React and its popular tool chain 'create-react-app' that makes bootstrapping a React app a breeze for developers, for no reasons other than their popularity and convenience afforded to developers in terms of shorter development time and its entrenched ecosystem‚Äî useful community‚Äôs guides, support, and libraries.

However, I have come to accept that these frameworks bloat, big time at that, to the detriment of end users, especially those with low-end devices(You ever used Typeform on a Moto G? Yeah it wasn't great I can tell you that). It gets worse when you throw in those ready-made libraries in the ecosystem, passing down the cost of Javascript to end users. Bottom line is, the wellness afforded to developers doesn‚Äôt necessarily trickle down to the end users.

We need to be more careful about this.

Further, there is a more pernicious effect of being a major user of a particular web framework: My whole intellect had been unwittingly locked into their walled-garden ecosystem: I spent so many hours doubled down on React, reading tons of articles on best practices and the ever changing suite of libraries that have gained traction in the community, to a point that I had forgotten about the existence of web standards and how much they had advanced since the peak of jQuery boom. If React and create-react-app were to disappear or fallen out of favor one day(and they will), I would have to start the learning process all over again, but this time dictated by a new throne and the influential thoughtleaders.

Well, guess what, now I have changed my ways.

I have gotten into the habit of looking for frameworks that are ‚Äòcloser to the metal‚Äô; those that are lightweight and respect the web standards, in this context, the native Web Component.

Here is a good place to start on Web component: open-wc

Other promising alternatives to React that are both lightweight and performant are hyperapp and preact although they are not exactly web standard compliant, plus, due to their implementation of Virtual DOM, they won‚Äôt be exactly kind to the precious resources of billions of users who happened to be born outside of the Western Wealthy Web.

VDOM diffing is just one of many examples of a framework choosing developer experience or simplicity of implementation over being frugal with their end-user‚Äôs resources. ‚Äî source

I have also stopped using ‚Äòcreate-react-app‚Äô to bootstrap my projects. I choose to learn to wire things up to solve my specific immediate needs. However, I need to be careful that I don‚Äôt fall to the temptation of ‚Äòreinventing the wheels‚Äô. I would search for narrow-focused, utilitarian, nano-size, framework-agnostic libraries as those utilized by the choojs framework. If the libraries are actively maintained, perfect. Otherwise, due to their small footprint in codes, I would be able to study their arts before I fork them. Though, should I failed to wrap my head around their codes, then I would be forced whipping one up myself.

For example, I most likely wouldn‚Äôt reinvent another state management solution like Redux even though I think I can pull it off myself, because Redux is already best at that without sacrificing extensibility. Another wheel you shouldn‚Äôt re-invent is authentication and encryption even though you think you can unless you are an expert in those particular domains.

Finding the Balance üåÑ

So how do we find a balance that meets our criterion for ethics, sustainability, and respects for web standards in this culture of relentless growth?

Although resourceful companies have been making their own strides in recognition of these issues, for budding businesses, I don‚Äôt see how we can meet halfway in the current climate of obsession for rocket-ship/hockey stick growth and ‚Äústruggle porn‚Äù where the ‚Äúmove fast and break things‚Äù ethos is deeply entrenched.

How do we adapt our business and personal aspiration with respect to these new expectations while taking care of everyone‚Äôs mental health well-being?

Because let‚Äôs face it, doing things right and ethical from the very beginning won‚Äôt fit into the time frame of today‚Äôs sprints.

In the face of perilous state of the world that's been incurring debts from the future for a very long time, those today who are in a privileged position‚Äî designers, developers, policy makers, entrepreneurs and capitalists‚Äî has a chance to accept that the growth process need to be slow, introspective and culturally meaningful rather than reckless, pompous, and presumptuous. And only then, will we ever be able to be proud of our works in every sense of the word. ‚óè
